awd_titl_txt: RUI: Applied dynamics and topology of aggregation systems
awd_abstract_narration:
In many natural systems, particles, agents, or organisms aggregate and display collective behavior. Aggregation systems include nanoparticle self-assembly, actin-filament networks in cells, and more. This project investigates aggregation systems with an eye towards insect swarms, bird flocks, fish schools, and other biological groups in which social interactions play a key role. The specific objectives are (1) to discover whether computationally challenging models can be accurately approximated with simpler, more tractable ones; (2) to use this understanding to model environmentally and economically destructive locust swarms; and (3) to classify complicated behavior in large data sets related to aggregations. The locust research impacts agriculture. In particular, it will yield insight on swarm suppression strategies. For instance, it may suggest crop-planting layouts that would avert the gregarious locust outbreaks that devastate farmers. Other key elements of this project, which is based at an undergraduate institution, include: extensive undergraduate student involvement and research training; a network of domestic and foreign colleges and universities; a pipeline from research to the classroom; enhancement of student research lab infrastructure; inclusion in research and advising activities of a female recent Ph.D. seeking a tenure-track position; a focus on the participation of underrepresented groups; and an educational public art exhibition on aggregations produced collaboratively with an undergraduate female artist and biology major.

The investigator and his colleagues study aggregation systems from continuum and discrete perspectives. A common aggregation modeling framework is conservation-type nonlocal PDE, which are analytically and computationally challenging. Degenerate Cahn-Hilliard approximations of a class of canonical models will be investigated with linear analysis, numerical simulation, phase plane analysis of equilibria, and a variational analysis of minimizers in order to evaluate the success of the local model in approximating the nonlocal one. Based on this understanding, the investigator will develop a model of phase polyphenic locusts interacting with the environment and use it to develop strategies that suppress destructive locust swarms. Stability analysis and numerical simulation will reveal environmental conditions likely to suppress a hysteretic bifurcation to a dangerous locust swarm. Finally, the investigator will characterize aggregation dynamics using topological data analysis. Data sets arising from numerical simulations and biological experiments will be analyzed with topological barcodes describing their persistent homology. This work will identify dynamical transitions in aggregation processes.

por.por_cntn:
Insect swarms, bird flocks, fish schools, and other aggregations may form in social biological groups composed of interacting individuals. We carried out several investigations of these groups.


First, in order to aid mathematical analysis, we performed a simplification on a mathematical model of aggregations and showed that the simpler model approximates the more challenging one. We then used this model as a testbed to investigate the interaction of organisms' social tendencies with their tendency to be influenced by environmental factors such as food sources. Within the framework of our model, we found that a random distribution of food sources tends to increase the peak crowding level of a social group, while a patterned distribution of food sources can reduce it. This result is relevant to locust swarms, which become dangerous at a particular density threshold.


Second, we constructed a model of marching locust aggregations known as hopper bands. The mathematical model is computationally challenging because it describes hundreds of thousands, millions, or possibly more interacting insects. We developed a fast computational tool to simulate our model, and using this tool, came up with a plausible and minimal set of biological mechanisms that can explain the formation of hopper bands.


Third, and somewhat more generally, we applied a class of tools known as topological data analysis to detect and classify complex dynamics in data describing animal aggregations. Topological data analysis studies data by considering is shape. This topological viewpoint is arguably a more agnostic view of data than summary statistics that are more commonly used, and we showed how topological data analysis can detect characteristics of aggregation dynamics that the more traditional measures miss.


This work was disseminated in several journal manuscripts and dozens of research talks.


In addition to these research activities, this project had several other impacts. It provided research training and experience to nine undergraduates, including several women (who are underrepresented in mathematics). The work supported interactions between the students and more senior scholars at institutions including Harvard University, Harvey Mudd College, University of Chicago, Northwestern University, University of British Columbia, and California State University at Northridge. Ideas related to the research on biological aggregations were incorporated into the PI's courses on mathematical modeling, differential equations, and more. The PI organized sessions related to the research at conferences of the Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics and Equadiff, and at an American Mathematical Society Mathematics Research Community.

Modified by: Chad M Topaz
